Re ''The Negatives of Recycling in New York,'' by John Tierney (Big City column, Aug. 8):

Perhaps our children's generation will no longer look at the costs of recycling in today's terms. They just might decide that the emission levels produced by today's sanitation trucks are unacceptable, and alternatives never thought of today will be considered.

The next generation could decide that the amount of packaging used by manufacturers of consumer goods and foods is appalling and force a change. Because of our recycling practices today, the ''disposable'' mentality of our society is gradually changing.

The costs of recycling in New York City might seem to be a heavy burden. Do we really have so little faith in the problem-solving ability and imagination of our children that we need to stop recycling because it costs more now?
